Primary_Text: Ai aalwiez disaid dat di wan dat waan tu stodi an waan bii sombadi kyan get dat.
Translated_Text: I decided a long time ago that the one who wants to study and is going to be somebody can get the money.

Primary_Text: Dat iz somting wat somwan shud luk intu.
Translated_Text: That is something someone should look into.

Primary_Text: [...] this was long before I was born - say they were living in this area, and they a- she ax through the settlement who move it - who move the conch off the line, and someone tell her. And this lady dau- ax her daughter if she move it in the night, and she - girl lie to her say, No, I didn't move it. And you know something? And they say when that girl was supposed to have that baby, she couldn'ta live with that baby, and her mother went down and ax her say, I hope you ain't eat them - that - that - uh, uh - that conch off that line. She say, Yeah, mama, I eat it. She say, Wait, let me go down to - to the lady and - and tell her it's you who eat that, because that was her cousin's daughter. And when she tell her that happen, she say, What? She say, Anyway, when you reach home, put the bucket down and pull her over the bucket, and they pull her over - pull her over the bucket, and you know, before she had that baby, she deliver something like a big piece of conch - from out of her stomach - first - before, and then after she had deliver that - then she deliver that baby.
Translated_Text: [...] and someone told her [...] And you know something? [...] she delivered something [...].

Primary_Text: Some I know - I know 'bout s- three girls and something like that - like when they had they children, I hear them say they find one in the toil- one in the toilet, they find one in the front of somebody door, yeah. They find a baby mus'e just born to the front of somebody door, and they say one time again they find one like through the bush in the garbage.
Translated_Text: [...] and something like that [...] they found one in front of somebody's door [...]. They found a newborn in front of somebody's door [...]

Primary_Text: jù gò si sɔmbɔdi wit ĩ̀ waif
Translated_Text: You will see somebody with his wife.

Primary_Text: wɛn jù tek sɔmtin nak àm wan
Translated_Text: when you knock it once with something

Primary_Text: I wantchee long you buy something.
Translated_Text: I want to buy something from you.
Someone killed him. OR: He has been murdered.

Primary_Text: Got somebody at the door. I wan something to eat.
Translated_Text: There is somebody at the door. I want something to eat.

Primary_Text: Yupla kisim wanpela meri tu na yupela go?
Translated_Text: Did you take a girl with you?

Primary_Text: Em save olsem samting rong long aus nau.
Translated_Text: She knew there was something wrong at home.

Primary_Text: hem i wan samting we sapos yu go tru long hol ia bambae yu yu wan laki man
Translated_Text: It was something that if you can go through the hole, you'll have lots of luck.

Primary_Text: Taem wan man hemi mekem wan komplen long ambudjman [...].
Translated_Text: When someone makes a complaint to the Ombudsman [...].
Like you and I tie up something, right?

Primary_Text: Bat sambala bin tok: "Yu labda kaman; woda gada gajimap wi."  Gudjob thad olgumen bin lafta mub.
Translated_Text: But some people said: "You have to come (because) the water is going to reach us." Just as well that woman had to move.

Primary_Text: Am kan gi am ēn gut obu di, as am nu overcharge am.
Translated_Text: He could give him something more, if he overcharged himself now.

Primary_Text: Am no kan bətróu fo gi di a ēntēnfuluk.
Translated_Text: He cannot trust to give it to anybody.
Some went with it (i.e. stole it).

Primary_Text: Nhu pádri purgunta, si algen sabe di algun inpidimentu di kel kasamentu, [...].
Translated_Text: The priest asked whether anyone knew of any impediment to this wedding [...].

Primary_Text: E pensa ma algun kusa ki kontise.
Translated_Text: He thought that something had happened!

Primary_Text: Se bo sintí falta d'un koza [...].
Translated_Text: If you feel you need something [...].

Primary_Text: Ma se un psoa falá ma bosê purtugês?
Translated_Text: But if somebody would talk to you in Portuguese?

Primary_Text: Kusaŋ tené baŋ awonti. ~ Alguŋ kusaŋ tené baŋ awonti.
Soku ê da mu ũa kwa.
Ê bê ũa ngê ka bi.
N sa ke fa txi kwa ũa.
Translated_Text: I'm going to tell you something.

Primary_Text: Aŋe si ver ad dize ki es asĩ purtəgez kẽ fal?
Translated_Text: If someone sees, (they) will say: "Who speaks Portuguese like this?".

Primary_Text: eli    kii tokaa see taan tafikaa   ooru
aki keensee teem voo,  pafaya   prenda, ravkiin?
Translated_Text: Is there someone here to teach, violin? OR: Is there anyone here to teach, violin?

Primary_Text: etuspa   un diiyapa   kiivoo  tadaa   vesli
Translated_Text: Wesley is giving them something or other per day.

Primary_Text: asii mee kii see  pooy teem
Translated_Text: It may be something like that.

Primary_Text: aluŋas tafalaa aka nikarasuportaa; isti mee losuportaa falaatu tafalaa
Translated_Text: Some say that [brand of tire] doesn’t withstand [the load]; only this [brand] withstands, they say.

Primary_Text: úngua jénti já kebrá aké práu
úngua angkóza já rintá na éli sa ólu
Yo nunte doy, nunte ki ki.
Translated_Text: I don’t have any money, I don’t have anything.
He gave me something. OR: He had something to give to me.

Primary_Text: Mas bueno que tiene tu algo que no hay nada.
Translated_Text: It is better that you have something than nothing.

Primary_Text: Tyéne kyen ya-abusá konel disuyo anák muhér na edad de syéte ányos.
Translated_Text: Somebody abused his seven year old daughter.

Primary_Text: Un hende a puntra pa bo.
I ta miná hende aí memo.
Gen yon moun ki pran plim mwen.
Gen yon bagay ki pike m.
M'wè yon moun nan lakou ou la yè swa.
Translated_Text: I saw someone in your yard last night.

Primary_Text: M wè yon moun nan lakou ou la yè swa.
Analyzed_Word: M wè yon moun nan lakou ou la yè swa.
Translated_Text: I saw someone in your yard last night.

Primary_Text: Bondjeu koz pa, non, li gen keken pou koze ak twa.
Translated_Text: God doesn't speak, he has somebody (else) to speak with you.

Primary_Text: Lot bout-la ina en dimoun ki gen plizyèr.
Translated_Text: On the other side there is somebody who has got several.
The/A person has died on my account.

Primary_Text: mbeni zo aga ti baa mo
Translated_Text: Someone came to see you. OR: Someone has come to see you.

Primary_Text: mo wara mbeni yi na ya ni?
mbeni yi laa asara lo a lege
Translated_Text: (Perhaps) something happened to her on the way.

Primary_Text: Mbeni, lo ken' ti sara ngia na koli ni.
Translated_Text: Another one, she refuses to chat with her husband.

Primary_Text: Mina bukile yena akha muye into.

Translated_Text: Someone who lacks ears doesn't hear.
I heard something following me from behind.

Primary_Text: izakán ána séregu hája ta zol ána bidáfa hája de árba marát
Translated_Text: If I have stolen something from somebody, I will pay for it four times.

Primary_Text: wáy min ítakum ma ámulu hája aʃán ágder rája fi béled
Translated_Text: None of you did anything in order to come back to the homeland.
Somebody passed here a long time ago.
A person by the name Xeczu bought something.

Primary_Text: Buku	ini	ada	orang	yang	tulis.
Translated_Text: This book was written by someone.

Primary_Text: Pehea la kanaka ma kela hale wau?
Translated_Text: Why is someone in my house? (official court translation)
Some people make it out of this one.
What do you have in your hand?
There's something lacking in your soup.
Someone will give us a ride.

Primary_Text: Kaba killiman miti hem na pasi, dem pulu sanni va hem, [...].
Translated_Text: And murderers came upon him on the road, they removed his things, [...].

Primary_Text: Dem sa moesoe sorie alle dem condre na bacara.
Translated_Text: They will have to show all their villages to the Europeans.

Primary_Text: Kaba dem fotto Ningre no jeri hem kwetikweti, na dem oure English plantasi dem habi hem.
Translated_Text: And the town blacks don't really know it, (but) on the old English plantations they say it.

Primary_Text: Den sama e luku en so duun.
Translated_Text: The people are staring at him.
Cows are on the path. OR: There are cows on the path.

Primary_Text: wen di poor piipl dem go we, di puliismaan dem kech di maan dem a rood, an kyar dem
Translated_Text: When the poor people had dispersed, the policemen caught up with the guys on the road and carried them to lock them up.

Primary_Text: wen wii heer about dem tingz dem dis wii doon noo wat tu do
Translated_Text: When we hear about these things, we don't know what to do.

Primary_Text: di dog an dem / di book an dem
Analyzed_Word: di	dog	an	dem	/	di	book	an	dem
Gloss: DET	dog	CONJ	3PL	 	DET	book	CONJ	3PL

Primary_Text: wan machiz; wan shuuz; wan ants
Translated_Text: a match; a shoe; an ant

Primary_Text: Suhm di tri dem laik de wuhz draiyin duhng.
Translated_Text: Some of the trees seemed to be waning.

Primary_Text: I ting (an/a dem) duhz duhn faas.
Translated_Text: We usually run out of the thing(s) quickly.

Primary_Text: Di buk-dem de pan di tiebl.
Translated_Text: The books are on the table.

Primary_Text: Ma grandfada had faiv eykaz a lan hia.
Translated_Text: My grandfather had five acres of land here.

Primary_Text: Maskin kaal op di sowdjaz dem.
Di pikniny dem we stodi Baptis taak di trii.
Translated_Text: The children who study at one of the Baptist schools talk the three (languages).

Primary_Text: Aafta di skiel gaan iin di sii batam [...].
Translated_Text: After the scales had fallen onto the bottom of the sea [...].

Primary_Text: Yo finganiel dem tuu long, sha!
Translated_Text: Your fingernails are too long, sir!

Primary_Text: So aal di animal neva kuda flai op.
Translated_Text: But not all of the animals could fly up [to the mountain top].

Primary_Text: Bot mai tiicha dei taak Inglish or Spanish.
Translated_Text: But my teachers, they talk English or Spanish.

Primary_Text: Som a di tiichaz dem don nou Inglish.
Translated_Text: Some of the teachers don’t know English.

Primary_Text: Nou wi hav les torkl dan ada animal.
Translated_Text: Now we find less turtles than other animals.

Primary_Text: Di muos praablem iz di drogz wid di yong man.
Translated_Text: For young men, the biggest problem are the drugs.

Primary_Text: Deh get som plaans fram FADCANIC laik ariinj, kokanat an ada ting.
Translated_Text: They get some plants from the FADCANIC like orange and coconut trees and other things.

Primary_Text: Miss - the boys - them broke down Bay Street.
Analyzed_Word: Miss	-	the	boys	-	them	broke	down	Bay	Street.
Gloss: Miss	 	ART	boy.PL	 	PL	break[PFV]	down	Bay	Street
Translated_Text: Miss, the men completely destroyed Bay Street.

Primary_Text: And girl, let me tell you. When you go to the Island - when you go to Island, try carry Off. Because them mosquito, they'll kill you - and them sandfly.

Gloss: [...]	PL	mosquito[SBJ]	3PL.SBJ.FUT	kill	2SG.OBJ	 	and	PL	sandfly[SBJ]

Primary_Text: dɛ pasɛnʤɛs tel àm se "mà frɛn [...]"
Translated_Text: The passengers said to him, "My friend [...]".

Primary_Text: wì gɛt sɔm wumã we dè dè kuk
Translated_Text: There were women who cooked (for us).

Primary_Text: dɛ trɔks we dè briŋg àm frɔm ʤɛmɛni
Translated_Text: the trucks they brought from Germany

Primary_Text: man dè̱m, got dè̱m, ston dè̱m

Translated_Text: How much are those bananas of yours?
May I ask whether all your children have been married?
Are there women on the ship?

Primary_Text: Like ten thousand of my friend already applied and went for interview.
Translated_Text: For example, ten thousand of my friends have already applied [for jobs] and gone for interviews.

Primary_Text: Then they teach you all the technique lah.
Translated_Text: Then they teach you all the techniques.

Primary_Text: Displa pik em i bin sae kaikaim ol man.
Translated_Text: This pig used to bite people.

Primary_Text: Em i stap nau ma(ma) bl' em wokim spia nao em i kam nau ma bl' em wokim ol bet.
Translated_Text: He stayed and his mother made arrows, he came and his mother made beds.

Primary_Text: D. im med langa ole boi.
Translated_Text: D. is mad with the boys.

Primary_Text: Yu kan tok la thislot medbaga.
Translated_Text: You can’t talk to these mad ones (children).

Primary_Text: Nomo gata lif, thislot botel tri.
Translated_Text: They don’t have leaves, these bottle trees!

Primary_Text: Yubala go gedim main daga. Nomo wori bla ola pipul.
Translated_Text: You lot go and get my food. Don’t worry about the people.

Primary_Text: Wi yusdu habim kid la bush.
Translated_Text: We used to have children in the bush.

Primary_Text: Imin ded silip eniwei la ola rok.
Translated_Text: He went sound asleep on the rocks.
I filled it up with the eggs.

Primary_Text: Imin polis treka olegija na, til imin hevim ole children.
Translated_Text: He was a police tracker for good then, until he had children.

Primary_Text: Yu bin ji ole nat [...] boling dan?
Translated_Text: Did you see the nuts falling down?

Primary_Text: Wal dislot bed, fram antop dei bin – dei bin lukinat na.
Analyzed_Word: Wal	dis-lot	bed,	fram	antop	dei	bin	–	dei	bin	luk-in-at	na.
Gloss: well	PROX-PL	bird	from	above	3PL	PST	 	3PL	PST	look-PROG2-out	now
Translated_Text: But these birds were watching from above.

Primary_Text: Ala munanga bin lus olabat shap [...] ebarrijing!
Translated_Text: The non-Aboriginals lost their shops [...] (all their) belongings!

Primary_Text: Wanbala olmen bin ran garrimap thad boks. Imin rekin im thad bigwan-bigwan peket.
Translated_Text: One old man ran and picked up that box. He reckoned it was those big packets.

Primary_Text: Ai bin gibitbat la ola kid tu sambala mani blanga plei.
Translated_Text: I was also giving the children some money for playing.

Primary_Text: Dumaji ai bin askimbat kwestyin la thad munanga na weya alabat wek jeya.
Translated_Text: Because I was questioning the non-Aboriginals who are working there.

Primary_Text: haʊ kæn smao ɹaks hit a ɹuf?
Translated_Text: How can small rocks hit a roof?

Primary_Text: if aʊa gɹænmaɾa tol as nokæn
Translated_Text: if our grandmothers told us we weren't allowed to

Primary_Text: deɪ gaɪz go baɪ dɛm sam soɾaz
Translated_Text: Those guys go and buy themselves some sodas.
Women paddle with short, quick strokes.

Primary_Text: eni bi eni das mini namapu kɛkɛ hatibeʃapu
Translated_Text: They say they swallow animals, such as bush deer.

Primary_Text: langi titi kɛnapu wa sɛtɛ kɛkɛ dalki titi kɛnapu ka
Translated_Text: People of long ago didn't live like people of nowadays.

Primary_Text: boek - boeke, dag - dae, man - mans, vrou - vrouens, kind - kinders
Translated_Text: book - books, day - days, man - men, woman - women, child - children

Primary_Text: Ê pa ka dexa kes káru bedju ánda más, pamô ses fumu sa ta pului ár kada bes más.
Translated_Text: These old cars shouldn’t be allowed to run any longer because their exhaust fumes are increasingly polluting the air.

Primary_Text: Amigus di Lusiu purgunta-l si e kreba entrába na djogu, más [...].
Translated_Text: Lusiu’s friends asked him if he wanted to join the game, but [...].

Primary_Text: Nos povu tenba ki vense, nos téra tenba ki liberta, nos ómi ku mudjer tenba ki vive na liberdádi, na pás y na pugrésu.
Translated_Text: Our people had to win, our country had to liberate itself, our men and women had to live in liberty, peace and progress.

Primary_Text: Ka kuma gosi ki minizu sa tudu ben bistidu.
Translated_Text: It is not like nowadays that children are all well dressed.

Primary_Text: Trabadjadoris, gosi sta karu pa bu po pa trabadja.
Translated_Text: Workers are now expensive for you to put to work.

Primary_Text: Galinha, porks e kes lá k no táva kriá.
Translated_Text: Hens, pigs, these were (the animals) that we used to rear.

Primary_Text: Mergulhadores, es mergulhador ta mufiná zóna d'péska.
Translated_Text: Scuba divers, these scuba divers spoil the fishing areas.

Primary_Text: Meius de komunikasãu tanben ta transmití-l.
Translated_Text: The media also transmit it (the information).

Primary_Text: Jent t'oiá kes káza lá de Madeiral.
Translated_Text: We can see those houses there from Madeiral.

Primary_Text: Ña karu ta lebá miñjer-us kabra-s kamati-s ku lansol-us pa fera.
Translated_Text: I usually take women, goats, tomatoes and sheets to the market in my car.
When the girls arrived, all the cauldrons were [already] occupied.
The mangos aren't tasty OR: The (particular) mango isn't tasty.

Primary_Text: Inen ngê se môlê ala me.
Ê ra Têtêuga ũa kiba palaxu pa Têtêuga ngodha ki mengai rê ki ene n'na rê.
Translated_Text: He gave Turtle a part of his palace for Turtle to enjoy it with his wife and his children.

Primary_Text: Ê tambu ane fuuta e bê ku ê kai.
Translated_Text: He took the breadfruits and went home with them.

Primary_Text: Ine laanza sê ki s'usan ê bôn fa.
Translated_Text: The oranges that are on the ground are not good.

Primary_Text: Ê tan laanza we ki sê.
Translated_Text: He left with oranges. OR: He took oranges and left.

Primary_Text: Ikəl tud koyz ki lɛvo nə museum father Marian ki lɛvo, nə?
Translated_Text: Wasn't it father Mariano who took those things to the museum?

Primary_Text: Yo a da kriãs pə tɛtɛ.
Translated_Text: I will give the children to (my) aunt.

Primary_Text: [...] tajuntaa luvaara andaatu, nosa jeentis doos pesaan tiɲatu, japapiyaa see, isti malvaars graasa tafaya [...]
Translated_Text: [...] having gone to a place where [they] get together, if two of our people stand and talk, the(se) Tamils ridicule [them].

Primary_Text: aka laraandu indum  meʃiin teem. meʃiins   teem taantu
Translated_Text: That aside, there is another machine. There are many machines. OR: That aside, [we] have another machine. [We] have many machines.
The file that we file our saws with?

Primary_Text: Ile ola tudu lay sorti di fula, di fruta fruta, di albër albër kung raisu [...].
Translated_Text: He saw all kinds of flowers, of fruit, of trees with roots [...].

Primary_Text: [...] tudu lay di bringku por fil filu.
Translated_Text: […] all kinds of toys for children.

Primary_Text: Cada hombre ya lliva tres bag.
Translated_Text: The men took three bags each.

Primary_Text: Mi tia y mi tio cuando ta queda frio ta hace sale el abrigo y mga camisa grueso.
Translated_Text: My aunt and my uncle, when it becomes cold, take out the coat(s) and thick shirts.
There are people in the house. OR: There is somebody in the house.
There are water buffalos on the road.

Primary_Text: E baka ta kome yerba; Baka ta kome yerba; E bakanan ta kome yerba; Bakanan ta kome yerba.
Translated_Text: The cow is eating grass. OR: Cows (in general) eat grass. OR: The cows are eating grass.

Primary_Text: Kachonan a keda grita henter anochi.
El a bin ku regalo(*nan) pa mi; El a bin ku regalonan mashá karu pa mi.
Translated_Text: He came with presents for me; He came with very expensive presents for me.

Primary_Text: Ta invitá tur amigu i konosí.
Translated_Text: All friends and acquaintances are invited.

Primary_Text: kaz-a, sa kaz-a, wonm-an, sa wonm-an,  kaz-ya, sa kaz-ya, moun-yan, sa moun-yan
Translated_Text: the house, this/that house, the man, this/that man, the houses, these/those houses, the people, these/those people
Children like to play. OR: Children love playing.

Primary_Text: Le vye moun parl en ta kreol.
Translated_Text: The old people speak a lot of Creole.

Primary_Text: Sa tou parl meriken akoz lez ekol.
Translated_Text: They all speak English because of the schools.

Primary_Text: Alors Bouki trapé eine dans la tchés-yé.
Translated_Text: Then Bouki grabbed one of the tails.

Primary_Text: Compair Lapin soté on la garlie ouké tou mamzels yé té apé tende li avé Compair Bouki.
Translated_Text: Brother Rabbit jumped on the porch where all the girls were waiting for him with Brother Bouki.

Primary_Text: Blan konm nwa te va pou chèche fonm nwa pou vini kote ye madonm.
Translated_Text: Whites and blacks alike went to get black women (i.e. midwives) to come to their wives (to deliver their children).
They're like (i.e. fight like) cats and dogs.

Primary_Text: I anvlop lé pié èk goni.
Translated_Text: You wrap the trees with gunny bags.

Primary_Text: Marmay i bouz pa; i sort laba, i di: E bin! papa, la di, nou l'arivé!
Translated_Text: The children do not move; they leave the place; they say: Well, daddy, they said, we have arrived!

Primary_Text: Sa mon banann, tou sa mon frui, ou la manzé la [...].
Translated_Text: These are my bananas, all that fruit you have eaten [...].

Primary_Text: Bann madanm i leve i danse.
Translated_Text: The women got up and danced.
The sisters came out from there.

Primary_Text: mek, te mek, kas, te kas

Translated_Text: There are rivers in St. Louis.

Primary_Text: sa, se tule mBla kom tule Nwar, se ndefa:ndi pu nu pu fe kom sa
Translated_Text: This is something that is forbidden to do for both Blacks and Whites.
That's the gun of the Whites.
There are a lot of people.

Primary_Text: lo sara agozo, lo sara ayi ti gongo na ni
Translated_Text: She prepared manioc and things, she prepared things to take.

Primary_Text: Kakoj gadula a nizənəj, isio ukalainza siuda pəliʃola.
Translated_Text: I do not know exactly in what year the Ukranians came here.

Primary_Text: Tiper' ibəŋka isio zenʃinə isio kərasivə.
Go itu tumman*(-pəðə) yang api məliyatna.
Translated_Text: I am going to visit those friends.

Primary_Text: Ada Melayu punya kawan-kawan campo-campo ada la.
Translated_Text: [I] have Malay friends, with whom [I] mix all the time.

Primary_Text: itu   gadis sama dia punya kawan

Translated_Text: The clove trees are all destroyed.

Primary_Text: Wau aole nana kela mau poho kiwi.
Translated_Text: I didn't see the buffalo horn containers (used for opium).

Primary_Text: Wau ike kela mau keiki akolu maloko nei.
Translated_Text: I saw three children inside here.
You make this lot stand up.

Primary_Text: Nyanawu kirri dei bin bringim im bihain wayi.
Translated_Text: You remember those women, they used to bring it at the back, didn't they.

Primary_Text: Dem manyanyi na ai laikim yapayapa.
Translated_Text: I like the young manyanyi leaves.
There turns out to be no grass for the guinea pigs.

Primary_Text: Kaaoshihtaachik lii maenzon lii rosh kiiaapachiheewak.
Translated_Text: When they made houses, they used rocks. OR: The houses that they made, they made of rocks.

Primary_Text: Dan mie dé soetoe na seysei, Boesieduyvie, Leguana ofoe Kauwrie na boon.
Translated_Text: Then I shoot bushpidgeons, iguanas, or jackdaws out of the trees on the sides (of the forest).

Primary_Text: Dem sa moessoe callie neem foe alla den hedieman foe dem condre.
Translated_Text: They will have to mention the names of all the captains of the/their villages.
The breasts are not getting bigger.

Primary_Text: a cat, two cat(s), all dem cat(s)
Translated_Text: a cat, two cats, all these cats

Primary_Text: dem cat, de cat an dem
A de taak bawt siywid dem.
Translated_Text: I am talking about those types of seaweed (that you know of).

Primary_Text: Sam a dem bway wuda gu awt.
Translated_Text: Some of the boys want to go out.

Primary_Text: Yu gat li aystaz we grow pan de.
Translated_Text: There are small oysters that grow on them.

Primary_Text: Ih haad fi poo pikniny go skuul.
Translated_Text: It is hard for poor children to go to school.

Primary_Text: Wen di pikniny dem hia dehn muma kom [...].
Translated_Text: When the children heard their mother coming [...].
We have a lot of problems.

Primary_Text: Som ov di madaz don sen di piknini tu klaas.
Translated_Text: Some of the mothers have sent their children to school.

Primary_Text: That when the Duke first come here, and he gone over to talk with R- President Roosevelt to see that he get to 'cruit some of the boys from here to go over there to work the Work Food Administration.

Primary_Text: First time I gone over - the first time I did gone off - let me tell you 'bout that. See, what happen, first in 1942, I work for the Royal Air Force. 1942 I work to the Royal Air Force Hospital. Yeah. And after 1942, then the Duke of Windsor gone aways to the - in the United State. He was acting government in the Bahamas. And after he see the condition of the people need a job, he gone over - oh, 'scuse me! He gone over and ... President Roosevelt and ax him if he could 'cruit some of the boys from here over there to work for the War Food Administration. And see, and I gone - I gone work for the War Food Administration.
And when he come back, he see this - he didn't believe in this martial law.
Translated_Text: [And when he (i.e. the Duke of Windsor) came back and] saw this - he didn't believe in martial law.

[...] omdat hy besig is om te werk
Translated_Text: [...] because he is busy working / [...] because he is (in the process of) working

Primary_Text: Hy hou aan dieselfde foute maak. — Sy hou aan hard werk.
Translated_Text: He keeps making the same mistakes. — She carries on working hard.

Primary_Text: Kelotu dia, kántu maridu sa ta benba di trabádju y k ’e sa ta pasába na un txáda, e átxa un kabésa riba-l pédra.
Translated_Text: The other day, when the husband was walking home from work and crossing a plain, he found a head lying on a stone.

Primary_Text: Ma y grinhasin, uk bo ti ta fazê?

Translated_Text: I will be going to school.

Primary_Text: Gósiŋ i ka podé kudí-bu parbiya i na tarbajá.
Translated_Text: He/she cannot answer you now because he/she is working.

Primary_Text: Iney ska fi wan xadyi namay.
Translated_Text: They are building a house for the family.
Teru is working (lit. Teru is doing work).
He is reading a book now.

Primary_Text: Agóra akí mótro ta kedá na Ternáte.
Translated_Text: Now we are living here in Ternate.

Primary_Text: Ta junta ilo cen para planta un casa.
Translated_Text: They are saving money to build a house.

Primary_Text: Nos ta bira protestant pa nos skapa di tur e molèster di pastornan, ku ta blo keda papia i menasá [...].
Translated_Text: We are becoming protestant in order to escape from the annoyance of priests who just keep on talking and threatening [...].

Primary_Text: Suto ta-ba kombesá ku besino si.
Translated_Text: We were talking to your neighbour.

Primary_Text: ta atra nde fe kwa se mata?
Translated_Text: What are you doing this morning?

Primary_Text: jer swar ma atra nde lir
se kwa sola atra nde fe?
Translated_Text: What are they doing at the moment?

Primary_Text: Jumari ah, dia banyak sibuk. Dia sedang sapu.
Translated_Text: [As for] Jumari, he is very busy. He is [in the process of] sweeping.

Primary_Text: Aole wau manao make ana wau, aka, wau nui loa eha keia manawa.
Translated_Text: I didn't think I was dying but I was in a lot of pain at the time.

Primary_Text: Dat warlakungkuma im kilimbatkarra dat biyu hawuj.
Translated_Text: The dog, he is hitting the bee's home.
A man keeps cutting the rope. OR: The man is cutting the rope.

Primary_Text: Da vool de slibi ([od.] siddom) na eksi tappo.
Translated_Text: The chicken is sitting on the eggs.

Primary_Text: Gado de sabi alla membre va wi, bevo wi pulu muffe na tongo.
Translated_Text: God learns all our thoughts, before we utter them.

Translated_Text: I’m sitting here thinking to rob a bank right now.

Primary_Text: Yu no e sabi a wet so bun.
Translated_Text: You don’t really know the law so well.

Primary_Text: Den e afrontu den tongo, tog.
Translated_Text: They turn their backs on their language, right.

Translated_Text: They don't want to speak Sranan Tongo anymore.

Primary_Text: Efu pikinso wan druppel nomo kisi yu skin, yu skin e bron.
Translated_Text: If even so much as a drop touches your skin, it burns.

Primary_Text: Mi ta wɔɔkɔ a di BOG.
A wooko di den uman sama e du na paandi goon.

Uh-huh, that's my friend. She always talking joke [...].

See the boy what park up going up the road? That's - uh - the boy what [...] He going up? Sit with the bag on he shoulder? You ain't see him? Oh, yeah, Rose was liking him. Yeah, uh-huh, yeah, Rose was liking him. Rose was liking him.

Translated_Text: the place that Hausa people pray in

Translated_Text: Now, when they come to Nima, they like it.

Primary_Text: À dè smɛl dì sɛnt fɔ̀ lɛ̀k haw è dè kuk plàntí.
Translated_Text: I smell the scent of him cooking plantain.

Primary_Text: Nà dis tin dè want kil yu.
Translated_Text: It's this thing [that] was about to kill you.

Translated_Text: I give her little things all the time.

Primary_Text: Tumɔro senwe à dè go mit ìn man.
Translated_Text: Tomorrow (emphasis) I'm going to go meet her husband.

Primary_Text: He still working in that company.
Translated_Text: He is working in that company.

mi stap hetem hem bifo finis
Translated_Text: I hated her already from before.

Primary_Text: Halideitaim yuno wi bin oldei wok dijey la Ivanhoe.
Translated_Text: In the holidays we used to walk over here to Ivanhoe station.

Primary_Text: Thed kainoba song na, wi neba bin askimbat alabat, dem olpipul.
Translated_Text: That kind of song, we never asked the old people about. OR: It [was] that kind of song [that] we never asked them [for], those old people, (Orig. Transl.)

Primary_Text: Mi lō lō a mi grani.
Translated_Text: I am going to my grandma.

Primary_Text: Mi ha fo lo werán a Ameriki, wapi sinu lo mā di flut sinu.
Translated_Text: I have to go to America again, where they make those flutes.

Primary_Text: Nu di hou man a ho di klēn jung lō blās də flute.
Translated_Text: Now the old man heard a little boy play the flute.

Primary_Text: Ek is aan die werk. / Ek is besig om te werk.

Gloss: 1SG.NOM	am	on	the	work	 	1SG.NOM	am	busy	INF.CONJ	to	work

Primary_Text: Kelotu dia, kántu maridu sa ta benba di trabádju y k ’e sa ta pasába na un txáda, e átxa un kabésa riba-l pédra.

Primary_Text: En fin, ago uji go nu sta dretu, nu ka sta pasa fomi.
Translated_Text: At least nowadays, we are well, we are not enduring hunger.

Translated_Text: Near over the ground sprout and grow: […]

Translated_Text: They believe in the miracles of the holy child.

Translated_Text: He works in Las Piñas [...]. [...] He comes home Saturday night and goes back early on Monday.

Primary_Text: Ta toma leche el muchacho todo el dia.

Translated_Text: [...] when s/he was still alive, X himself/herself used to give me candies.

Primary_Text: Mi ta gusta esei un mundo.
Mi ta drechando un auto kual mi lo bende despues.
Translated_Text: I am repairing a car which I will sell afterwards.

Primary_Text: Hende grandinan di ántes tabata traha hopi kos di boka dushi ku a disparsé òf ta disparsiendo.
Translated_Text: The old people of earlier times used to prepare many sweets that have disappeared or that are disappearing.

Primary_Text: E kos ta bayendo hopi leu.
E papel ku mi ta uza aworaki ta papel di saka kopia.
Translated_Text: The paper that I now use is photocopy paper.

Primary_Text: E ta ranka paña fo’i waya, koba buraku den kurá, kibra mata, [...] i hopi kos mas.
Translated_Text: It will pull clothes off the line, dig holes in the yard, break plants [...] and do many more things.
I cannot (go along) with this. = This is not for me. OR: This is not my kind of thing.

Primary_Text: Entèl t ap vin; se paske i malad i pa vini.
Translated_Text: He/She would be welcome; it is because he/she is sick that he/she hasn't come.
He/She will be sick. OR: He/she is getting sick (inchoative).

Primary_Text: M ap vin wè ou demen.

He likes to meet me in town.

M ap vini bek byen vit.

Translated_Text: He was playing when I came.

tere agwe (a)duti na yanga ti yaka ti kobe so [...], ake te

Translated_Text: These days Francine works in a restaurant.

Translated_Text: In Sudan people can only remain silent.

Translated_Text: Schools usually start in September in Port Sudan.

Translated_Text: [Please] eat. I still have more noodles.

The two of them were staying.

Primary_Text: Wau noho hana kamana ma ka mahiko o Makaweli ma nehinei.
Translated_Text: I was working in carpentry at Makaweli sugar plantation yesterday.

Translated_Text: That person boasts, he is a real boaster, he likes to boast.

Translated_Text: My beloved brother, I love you with true love.

Primary_Text: Wi de jam nanga makandra vo kroboi.

Primary_Text: Den ben lafu unu taki unu no ben gwenti si trein.

Primary_Text: A pikin e krin en kamra.

Primary_Text: Ma yu no musu du den sani dati.

Translated_Text: They used to cultivate their farm and so  on, and they used to stay there.

Translated_Text: The teacher usually administers a lot of licks.

Primary_Text: Dodo de tro di krefiʃ in de i musa de tink dat.
Translated_Text: When Dodo throws the lobster in it (ice-box), he must think that. OR: When Dodo (fisherman) throws the lobster into his ice-box, that's what he must think (he calls his ice-box "Bugs' Graveyard").

Primary_Text: A mek dat wen sizan de an en de wok krefiʃ.
Translated_Text: I make that when the season is on and I work lobster. OR: I earn (as much money) when during the lobster season.
We are not paying attention to that.

Primary_Text: Ihn stody du dat evry die!
Ai yuuztu go chorch beefut, widout shuuz.

Primary_Text: An di biich, a lat a baril yuuztu apier.
Translated_Text: On the beach, a lot of barrels would appear.

Primary_Text: Di oubia wuman no stodi meek era.
Translated_Text: The obeah woman wasn’t in the habit of making mistakes.
Plenty people are in the habit of coming.

Primary_Text: They does steal away, when they get in the job, they steal away, especially - if they - have - a big position, and they handling the money, they take so much - out, they go for big, big, big, big money.
Translated_Text: They just leave [...] [especially when they are in a big position which involves] handling the money, [they take some of it and go for even bigger money].

Primary_Text: And you know in that settlement, used to be ten years, five years before somebody dies. Yeah, 'cause we - we - we eating - we ain't know - know nothing about no high blood and no - no - uh - diabetes and - and cancer and things like that, 'cause we were eating straight from the farm, you know. So those people was strong, they used to live 80, 90, a hundred years. Old people, on the Island. And now - every week, so much of young. Yeah, when I [...] open the papers on Thursday, I see the o- I say, You live good. Live a ripe old age. 27, 26, people dying from AIDS and this and that.
Translated_Text: [...] in that settlement, it used to take ten years, [five years,] before somebody would die [again] [...] because we were eating [...] we were eating straight from the farm [...] So those people were strong, they used to live 80, [90, a hundred] years [...].

Translated_Text: How do you / did you cook hog maw?

Primary_Text: She be telling people she eight.
Translated_Text: She is always telling people she is eight. OR: She generally tells people that she is eight years old.

Primary_Text: Some of them be big and some of them be small.
Translated_Text: Generally, some of them are big and some of them are small. OR: It is usually the case that some of them are big and some of them are small.

Translated_Text: [...] we usually meet/met in a car.

Translated_Text: When I would repeatedly do like this, I wouldn't feel [the] heat.

Primary_Text: Ɛni de dɛ̀n dè chɔp rɛs, ɛni de.
Translated_Text: Every day they eat rice, every day.

Primary_Text: Yu save raitim nem bilong yu?
Translated_Text: Do you know how to write your name?

Translated_Text: In the local language they call him Ipopadje.

Primary_Text: Mipela ol Papua Niugini i save kaikai kaukau long nait.
Translated_Text: We Papua New Guineans usually eat sweet potato at night.

Primary_Text: olgeta oli stap yusum fasin blong bifo yet
Translated_Text: They still do things the old-fashioned way.

Primary_Text: ol SDA oli no save kakae mit
Translated_Text: Seventh Day Adventists don't eat meat.

Primary_Text: Wi yusdu habim kid la bush, ani wi neva habim [...] melk, wi yusdu go bek bo olden taim.
Translated_Text: We used to have children in the bush, but [sometimes] we didn't have milk, we used to go back to the old timer [treatment].
She used to like to drink.

Primary_Text: Di difi sini am a kan goi mais mi ris gi sini.
Translated_Text: To the doves, he used to throw corn and rice to them.

Primary_Text: Na kel ténpu, buru ta karága kárga.
Translated_Text: In those days, loads used to be carried by donkeys.

Primary_Text: Ami, N ka ta kredita na bruxariâ, N ta kre so na kusa ki ten un splikason lójiku.
Translated_Text: As far as I am concerned, I don't believe in witchcraft; I only believe things that can be explained logically.

Primary_Text: N ta ser grándi un dia.
Translated_Text: One day I will have grown up.

Primary_Text: Nu ta fika ku bontadi di panha otu, ma ka ten.
Translated_Text: We would long for more but there was not anymore.

Primary_Text: N ta lenbra kuma nu tinha, tinha falta.
Translated_Text: I remember that we were in need.

Primary_Text: N fra-z, kuazi N ta bai Praia.
Translated_Text: I told them that maybe I will go to Praia.
I will not tell any more (stories).

Primary_Text: Entre kunpanher no ta falá kriol.
Minjeris di li ta bambu se mininus.
Translated_Text: Women here carry their children on the back.

Primary_Text: Bu ta bin nha kasa amanha.
Tudu diya, N ta kumé na fugoŋ.
Translated_Text: I eat in the kitchen every day.
The palm tree will not die.
Others, on their turn, work as palm wine extractors.
I was living there. OR: I used to live there.

Primary_Text: Sun ka bê ngê ka vala.
Olo ma a ka tê m'me, a ka n'dja laba mo.
Translated_Text: When one is going to eat, one has to wash one's hands.

Primary_Text: Amanhan n ka romosa ki Zwan.
Translated_Text: Tomorrow I'll have lunch with Zwan.
My grandfather speaks little to me.

Primary_Text: Tempu seku no xa té fo medyi maiu.
Translated_Text: The dry season starts in the month of May (lit. The dry season we have it from the month of May).

Primary_Text: Muda-ni dəpəy doy, kindz di su dɛt tə li͂pa.
Translated_Text: After replanting (the sprouted rice shoots), (the fields) are cleaned from two to fifteen days afterwards.

Primary_Text: senaa, noospa janasa poɖiyaaspa nosa lingvaay seensaba kiteem
Translated_Text: Otherwise, the children born to us don't know our language.

Primary_Text: el lo falá ku sa mai pai ke da seng
Translated_Text: He (the potential groom) would tell his parents that he wanted to become engaged.

Primary_Text: Riba e isla aki ta biba un mion hende.
Translated_Text: On this island live a million people.

Primary_Text: E sa uzé ora ku e kièr tene su kabei ariba den otro.
Translated_Text: She uses it (habitually) when she wants to keep her hair tied up.
We make the soup this way.

Primary_Text: Kòlbè konn vann liv bò isi a.
Translated_Text: Kolbe usually sells books around here.

Primary_Text: Alor, in zour, lavé in boug, li avé in kamarad ali [...]. Lé dé i fé parti la sas avek, tou le tan.
Translated_Text: Once upon a time there was a man, he had a companion [...] The two of them used to go hunting together, all the time.

Primary_Text: Me malerezman mon pa fime, mon frer, mon sik taba.
Translated_Text: But unfortunately, I don't smoke, my brother, I chew tobacco.

Primary_Text: tongana lo mu samba na ala, ala ken', ala tene, baa ala nyon'ka samba pepe
Translated_Text: When he offers you beer, refuse, say, "Look, I don't drink beer."

Primary_Text: [...], mo teen', baa, mo nyon' samba ape o
Translated_Text: (When he offers you beer), say, "Look, I don't drink beer, thank you."

Primary_Text: kíla bakán ta bi-rúo logó núbi
ána bifékir obóma de ma kwes
Translated_Text: I guess that oboma is not good.

Primary_Text: yúmkin íta birákabu ákil bi lel íta bikútu fi talája
Translated_Text: You could cook the food at night so as to put it in the refrigerator.

Primary_Text: sána jái de úo bikun abúna
Translated_Text: Next year he will be a priest.

Primary_Text: henák fi sudán nas binum bédri
Translated_Text: In Sudan people usually go to sleep early.

Primary_Text: kan úo ma der mótoro rája le nas mótoro ma binénzil
Translated_Text: If he doesn’t want the rain to come back to the people, the rain won’t fall down.

Sometimes, we spoke very little Hokkien.

Primary_Text: [...] dulu Hainan punya orang ah tak pandai la.
Translated_Text: [...] before, the Hainanese were not skillful.

Translated_Text: Why do you usually want to see Edith?

Translated_Text: I usually was unable to care for my family.

Translated_Text: And the kids used to go there stealing the tomatoes, I think.
The house is falling down. OR: The house keeps falling down.

Primary_Text: Wie ben dee aksie na wan Nefie.
Translated_Text: We were asking for a knife.

Primary_Text: A de drungu, a no kann go reti, a de kanti.
Translated_Text: He is drunk, he cannot go straight, he is tilting.

Primary_Text: Kwándo kel no sábe yo asé kosíw.
Translated_Text: Before I didn’t know how to prepare food.

Primary_Text: No di sentí, no di sabé.
Translated_Text: They will not notice, they will not know.

Primary_Text: Mirá tédi, ya sabé ya tédi?
Pensaba mi hermano frio el agua.
Translated_Text: My brother thought that the water was cold.

Primary_Text: Ta pinsa mi hermano que frio daw el agua.
Translated_Text: My brother thinks that the water is cold.
I assumed that it is still early.

Primary_Text: Ni Antonio ni Maria no ta na kas.
Translated_Text: Neither Antonio nor Maria are home.

Primary_Text: Mi tanta tawata na Aruba pa dos siman.
Translated_Text: My aunt was in Aruba for two weeks.
And this meal, how was it?

Primary_Text: M ole to det là jou-la, dimonch.
Translated_Text: I want you to be there that day, Sunday.

Primary_Text: Petet to va pa et satisfe.
Dolo se jolimon bon pou met twa.
Translated_Text: Water is very good for throwing you in.

Primary_Text: Mwen lé byen kontan. — Mwen lété byen kontan. — Mi sra byen kontan.
Translated_Text: I am very pleased. — I was very pleased. — I'll be very pleased.

Primary_Text: Sa k i vé alé la kantin i sava.
Translated_Text: Whoever wants to go to the pub [can] go.

Primary_Text: Kalau lu apa-apa sal ada mau cakap, lu kasi la tahu ah sekarang.
Translated_Text: If you have anything you would like to say, let me know now.

Primary_Text: Mi no ha tiffi moro, mi no kann kau.
Translated_Text: I don't have teeth anymore, I cannot chew.

Primary_Text: Da somma no sabi va swem.
Translated_Text: That person cannot swim (doesn't know how to swim).

Primary_Text: Ju sa mann va tjarri datti?
Translated_Text: Are you able to carry that?

Primary_Text: Da mastra a za wandi fo slibi lange mi na netti  kaba a za fom mi alle de.
Translated_Text: The master, he will want to sleep with me in the night, and he'll beat me up every day.

Primary_Text: Den kan e wakti unu na oso.
Translated_Text: They may be awaiting us at home.

Primary_Text: A kan de taki Jan ben sribi kaba.
Translated_Text: It’s possible that John was already asleep.

Primary_Text: Mi kan go na+a dansi bika(si) mi abi moni.
Analyzed_Word: Mi kan go na+a dansi bika(si) mi abi moni.
Gloss: 1SG can go LOC the.SG dance because 1SG have money
Translated_Text: I can go to the dance because I have money.

Primary_Text: A taánga téee. A sa hópo wán hóndo kiló.
Translated_Text: S/he is strong, s/he can lift a hundred kilos.

Primary_Text: A taanga, a sa diki wan ondoo kilo.
Translated_Text: He is strong, he can lift one hundred kilos.

Translated_Text: They probably were telling lies on me.

Primary_Text: Di seim ting we i lokin fa outsaid i kod get it insaid.
Translated_Text: Whatever he is looking for outside can be obtained inside.

Primary_Text: Maas Jan se im kyahn kom tumaro.
Translated_Text: Mr. John said he is able to come tomorrow.

Primary_Text: Maas Jan se im kyahn kom tumaro.
Translated_Text: Mr. John said it is possible for him to come tomorrow.

Primary_Text: I kuda me gɛt wan job da big krik.
Translated_Text: He could have got a job at Big Creek.

Translated_Text: He heard about a lady who could cure any kind of illness.

Translated_Text: Is it possible to find a head without a tongue?

Primary_Text: Dei kaan rait nat wan ting.

Primary_Text: Haitian? But I like 'em, because - I say all is God people, and some of them have good ways. You know, have good ways, yeah. Some of them nice, but you could find some ain't nice, but some of them nice.

Primary_Text: Yeah, [...] learn a different speech, eh. Now you could speak - how much - how much you coulda speak? Two?
Translated_Text: [...] So you can speak [...] - how many different [languages] can you speak?

Primary_Text: [So you think that's the reason?] I 'most believe, could be, yeah.
Translated_Text: I almost believe [that], [that] could be [the reason], [yeah].

Translated_Text: [...] [if you catch the crab, don't hold it by the biter, because] you might get bitten.

Translated_Text: We can do it tomorrow. OR: We will be able to do it tomorrow.

Primary_Text: You can perhaps/possibly hear the engine.
Translated_Text: You can perhaps/possibly hear the engine.

Translated_Text: The possum won't be able to see it.

Translated_Text: His girlfriend took something like five thousand (vatu = money).

Translated_Text: Don't swear there [...] because something might happen.

Translated_Text: You don't wash your hair because it might fall off.

Translated_Text: I could nail anything from here until in the path (refering to his former ability with bow and arrow).

Primary_Text: en ka alwes jɛ di mingi ben ka
Translated_Text: They cannot be in the water forever.

Translated_Text: One can travel to Portugal by ship or by plane.

Translated_Text: It is possible that Pedro is sick, he has not arrived yet.

Translated_Text: He did not come today, but he is likely to come tomorrow.

Translated_Text: He didn't come today but perhaps he will come tomorrow.

Translated_Text: He/she may/might come tomorrow but I am not sure of that.

Primary_Text: N na ka pô mata bô fa.
Translated_Text: I can’t kill you. OR: I'm unable to kill you.

Primary_Text: Ê ka pô bila bi nganha.

Primary_Text: Aie ê ka pô thêka foga.
N na ka pô ngana Alê fô.

Primary_Text: Ê ka po sa ya ê sa lala.

Primary_Text: eli sabé nadá ati ila grandi

Translated_Text: It is possible that I was born like this. OR: It is possible that my mother gave birth to me like this.

Primary_Text: Di pode llega el carta mañana.

It seems to me that it was on that day.
It seems to me that it fell.

Primary_Text: I parsí-m kumá i na cobé awosi.
Translated_Text: It seems to me that it will rain today.

Primary_Text: Palêsê êlê ku mosu dê ka bi n’ũa vapô.
Translated_Text: Apparently s/he and the boy arrive in a boat.
It seems that rain is coming.
It seems that rain is coming.
This man seems to be a good singer.

Primary_Text: Parɛs use tiŋ nə Una õt.
Translated_Text: It seems you were in Una yesterday.
It seems that it will rain tomorrow.
It seems [they] have sold the car too. OR: And it seems they have sold the car. OR: It seems they have even sold the car. OR: It looks like they have sold their car.
It seems (to me) it will rain.
It seems (to me) rain is coming. OR: It seems (to me) it is going to rain.
It doesn't seem (to me) that it will rain.

Primary_Text: Ta pareci que dela niso paga con ele el debe mañana.
Translated_Text: It seems that we must pay him the debt tomorrow.
It seems that Peter is not here.

Primary_Text: [...] nos por nota ku último tempu aki parse ku violensia a oumentá hopi.
Translated_Text: [...] we can see that, recently, [it] seems that violence has increased a lot.

Primary_Text: A palesé ke ané a morí.
Li sanble l gen yon pwoblem.
Translated_Text: He seems to have a problem.

Primary_Text: Li sanble l p ap vini ankò.
Translated_Text: It seems he isn't coming anymore.
It seems that he is ill.
It seems that he is ill.

Primary_Text: Sa sòm kòm si l ale fe lapli.
Translated_Text: It looks like it is going to rain.

Primary_Text: Sanm kòm si, dan le jen jan-le, kichòw e kouri pli mal kè janmen.
Translated_Text: It seems as though among young folks, something is going worse than ever.

Primary_Text: I resanb zot lé plin de pou dan la tet.
Translated_Text: It seems that their heads are full of lice.

Primary_Text: li paret ki nu 'n fer erer
Translated_Text: It seems that we've made a mistake.

Primary_Text: paret ki lapli pu toṁbe daṅ en ti mama
Translated_Text: It seems that it will start raining in a moment. OR: It seems that it will start raining in a little while.

Primary_Text: li paret ki fin ena en kudeta
Translated_Text: It seems that there has been a coup d'état.

Primary_Text: I paret mwan ki laplipar ou letan ou 'n fer lo zil.
Translated_Text: It seems to me that you spent most of your time on the islands.

Primary_Text: I pa paret ki Tom i la.
Translated_Text: It doesn't seem that Tom is there.

Primary_Text: Pa paret ki Tom i la.
Translated_Text: It doesn't seem that Tom is there.

Primary_Text: Ti paret ki Tom i la.
Translated_Text: It Seemed that Tom was there.

Primary_Text: I pa ti paret ki Tom i la.
Translated_Text: It did not seem that Tom was there.

Primary_Text: Yandi kée mon-ána bónso yándi kée na  maládi
Yandi kée mon-íka bónso yándi kée na maládi
mbi baa mbi tene, i duti na ala aninga mingi
Translated_Text: I think that we've been with you a long time.

Primary_Text: mbi panze mbi tene lo ga biri
ya gi-bén rután de gu-ró wóduru
Translated_Text: It seems that this language will disappear.

Primary_Text: gebéynu kan ánna géni ketír kalás
Translated_Text: It seems like we have stayed long enough.

Primary_Text: Maja dumaj palawina sonʧa kanʧaj, dəlugoj betir najdi esi.
Translated_Text: I think that in the afternoon the wind will change the direction.
It seems that dinner is ready.
It seemed that Miflal went to school.

Primary_Text: Ini macam 	sula	tau 	paham	saya	pinya	celita.
Translated_Text: It seems [as if you] have already known [and] understood my language.
I think he has got up.

Primary_Text: Wau manao akahi pihi nui iaia paani kela wai.
Translated_Text: I thought that a huge fish was playing in the water. (describing the characteristics of a loud sound made during a landslide) OR: It seemed as if a huge fish were playing in the water.  OR: It sounded like what a huge fish playing in the water would sound like.
It seems as though we have been talking all day.
It was a long time since he had seemed like a person.
She seems to be in disfavor with her friends. OR: Seemingly she is hated by her friends.

Primary_Text: Zhipaans aasey ooshaam kinweesh oota kitayaanaan.
Translated_Text: It seems (that) we have stayed long enough.
It seems (that) we have stayed long enough.
Perhaps it will be good weather tomorrow.

Primary_Text: Gongosaman de jette na une middri.
Translated_Text: There are still hypocrites amongst you.
There is no drop of water here.

Primary_Text: Mastra wini no de na battra.
Translated_Text: Master, there is no wine in the bottle.
There is no help. OR: There is nothing to be done.

Primary_Text: Kaba alwassi so menni fissi ben de, tog netti no brokko.
Translated_Text: But although there were a lot of fish, still the net did not tear.

Primary_Text: Den  abi  wan singi e    singi taki lespeki no  de moro.
Translated_Text: There’s a song that says that there’s no respect anymore.

Primary_Text: Merki no de srefisrefi a foto.
Translated_Text: There isn’t any milk at all in town.

Primary_Text: do taim laik di din gat iiryiiyeetid jringk su moch lek nou
Translated_Text: At that time aerated [carbonated] drinks weren't as plentiful as they are now.

Primary_Text: luk dong so gat o chrii
Translated_Text: Look, there is a tree down so.

Primary_Text: It have rum in de house.
Translated_Text: There is rum in the house.

Primary_Text: In de yard have tri cow.
Translated_Text: There are three cows in the yard.

Primary_Text: Pikni fo so de a beisaid.
Translated_Text: There are lots of children at the bayside. OR: A lot of children are at the bayside.

Primary_Text: Yu gat som piipl we groj yu fi evriting yu gat.
Translated_Text: There are some people who covet everything you have.

Primary_Text: I gat mora wan tiŋ we a de tiŋk bowt.
Translated_Text: There is more than one thing that I'm thinking about.

Primary_Text: Ga li aystaz we grow pan dem.
Translated_Text: There are little oysters that grow on them.

Primary_Text: Yu had di djadj yu had dis seym gavmɛn laya.
Translated_Text: There was the judge, and there was that government lawyer.

Primary_Text: Tu moch hous iina Nort End.
Translated_Text: There are too many houses in North End.
There are many beaches on San Andrés.

Primary_Text: Wi gat moa an wan pasability.
Translated_Text: There is more than one possibility.
There are (too) many people in this house.

Primary_Text: Ih hav iz a stori wid trii chalinj.
Translated_Text: It is a story with three challenges.

Primary_Text: Ai tink Bluufiilz gat mor piipl spiikin Kriol.
Translated_Text: I think there are more people who speak Creole in Bluefields.

Primary_Text: Wi yuuztu hav piipl huu hont.
Translated_Text: There were people who hunted in our community.

Primary_Text: Aktuali, Tasba hav a praimari skuul.
Translated_Text: At present, there is a primary school in Tasbapauni.

Primary_Text: Dier wil aalwiez aalwiez bii dat somting mait hapn tu yu.
Translated_Text: There will always, always be the possibility that something might happen to you.
There are plenty people in this (specific) house.

Primary_Text: It's - it's all kind of stories about the Shine [...].
Translated_Text: There are all kinds of stories [about the Shine] [...].

Primary_Text: Or then if you want know more further, you could go 'round the House of 'Sembly [...] - not down the House of 'Sembly, but up Court, and - you see, they get plenty CID there, you could ax 'em - if they - just ax 'em.
Translated_Text: [Or then, if you wanted to know more, you could pass by the House of Assembly] [...], [at the Court,] there are many CIDs there, [you could ask them] [...].

Primary_Text: The people was nice, and everything. You going 'round, they used to treat you good. Had nice people - I get nice girlfriends and thing.
Analyzed_Word: Had	nice	people	-	I	get	nice	girlfriends	[...]
Gloss: have.PST.EXIST	nice	people	 	1SG.SBJ	get.PST.POSS	nice	girlfriend.PL	[...]
Translated_Text: [The people were nice and everything. You went around - they used to treat you well.] There were nice people there - I had nice girlfriends [and [every]thing.]

Primary_Text: [Turtle, is there much turtle now?] No, don’t have turtle round.
Translated_Text: [Are there many turtles here now?] No, there aren’t any turtles here.

Primary_Text: Only be three live here, my husband and just that little grand.
Translated_Text: There are only three (people) living here, [my husband (and me) and that little grandchild].

Primary_Text: It/Dey got a lot of books on the table.
Translated_Text: There are a lot of books on the table.

Primary_Text: Got a lot of books on the table.
Translated_Text: There are a lot of books on the table.

Primary_Text: dɛn gɛt bɔku pipul dɛm de
Translated_Text: There were a lot of people there. OR: A lot of people were there.
There is food on the table.

Primary_Text: wì gɛt difrɛn fɔrɛnɛs we dè dè kam
Translated_Text: There are different foreigners who come.

Primary_Text: Wan yam i dey fo tabul.
Translated_Text: There is one yam on the table.

Primary_Text: Plenti pipul dem dey fo haus.
Translated_Text: There are many people in the house.

Primary_Text: [...] è no gɛt tɔk nà Pichi.
Translated_Text: [...] there's no word (for that) in Pichi.

Primary_Text: Say no de fɔ̀ was han?
Translated_Text: Is there no place to wash (one’s) hands?
Are there any oysters in the market?

Primary_Text: There is food on the table.
Translated_Text: There is food on the table.
There is food on the table.

Primary_Text: Long Wara Sipik tu em i gat kain kain ol masalai nabaut i stap.
Translated_Text: In the Sepik River area there are also all kinds of spirits.

Primary_Text: Bipo bipo tru i gat wanpla man.
Translated_Text: A long long time ago there was a man.

Primary_Text: long ples ia i no gat fulap si ok
Translated_Text: Around here, there aren't very many sea oaks.

Primary_Text: Gat orlem fish daun iin' soltworta.
Translated_Text: There are fish (distributive plural) in the sea.

Primary_Text: I gotim big gata maitbi theya, thetsaid.
Translated_Text: Maybe there is a big gutter, on that side.

Primary_Text: Hiya, samwe raun hiya, i gata keib theya.
Translated_Text: Here, somewhere around here, there is a cave.

Primary_Text: Thei reken i gota ngalanymuwa, bifo thei bin oldei getim.
Translated_Text: [At that place] they think there are echidnas, in the old days they used to catch them.
There are golden apples on it. / It has golden apples.

Primary_Text: Ēen tid di a ha ēn frou.
Translated_Text: Once upon a time there was a woman.
Bad people are everywhere. OR: There are bad people everywhere.

There was a floor under the shelter.

Primary_Text: Dentu kel lagúa, ten un pédra-mármi, [...].
Translated_Text: In this lake, there lies a stone of marble, [...].

Primary_Text: Si ka ten nada di kume, nu ta ferbe-l o nu ta kuzinha-l.
Translated_Text: If there is nothing to eat, we boil it or we cook it.

Primary_Text: Ten txeu amdjer e k ta bá peská.

Primary_Text: I ten un igreja na e prasa.
Translated_Text: There is a church in this town.

Primary_Text: *Kasa ten vs. I ten un kasa.
Translated_Text: NOT: *Exists a house vs. There is a house.

Primary_Text: I teŋ arus ciw na Sindoŋ.
Translated_Text: There is plenty of rice in Sindone.
There is no problem. OR: Everything is okay.

Primary_Text: Ê tê ome ku sêbê kuji kume bwa so.
Translated_Text: There are men that know how to cook very well. (OR: She has a husband who knows how to cook very well.)

Primary_Text: Ê tê dja ku n na ka kume fa.
Translated_Text: There are days on which I don't eat.

Primary_Text: Tepu nakulu kwanda tia ta tê ũa ome.
Translated_Text: In the olden days, in the highlands, there was a man.

Primary_Text: Ê tê ningê nhon di pasa lala fa.
Translated_Text: There is nobody who passes by over there.

Primary_Text: Tê ningê nhon di pasa lala fa.
Translated_Text: There is nobody who passes by over there.

Primary_Text: Xa suku xa vida ba dentsy, [...].
Translated_Text: So there was some life in the future, [...].

Primary_Text: N-əkə kadz mwit mɔt jɛ̃t tɛ.
Translated_Text: There are very many people in that house.

Primary_Text: teng tantu pesua na isti kaza
Translated_Text: There are many people in this house.

Primary_Text: Nu meo di matu teng ung pos grandi.
Translated_Text: In the middle of the forest, there was a big well.

Primary_Text: Tiene nah rio ung grande bangka motor [...].
Translated_Text: There is a big motor boat on the river [...].

Translated_Text: There are still plenty of potatoes in the refrigerator.
There are people who eat a lot.

[...] there's a Portuguese guy in the group.

Primary_Text: Te gen anpil moun nan kay la.

Primary_Text: Gen twa chanm nan kay la.

There are a lot of people.
There are a lot of people.
There are a lot of people.
There are a lot of people.

Primary_Text: gen timoun yé pa pouvé ké yé kò
Translated_Text: There are children who are physically very weak.

Once upon a time there was a lady.

Primary_Text: Ye gen en plas ye pèl Scotland.
Translated_Text: There's a place they call Scotland.

Primary_Text: Ye te janmen gen pir blan dan la Louzyaen ye tou mele.

Primary_Text: Te konnen gen ti ti betay-ye on le fey koton-ye.

There is a lot of work.
There were three brothers, three boys [...].
There is nobody who will know [that you killed him].

Primary_Text: na a ŋgra laport ʃe mwa
Translated_Text: There is a big door at my place.
There is food on the table. OR: The food is on the table.

Primary_Text: akete kete amicrobe ti bilharzie ni ake na ya ti ngu so
Translated_Text: Very small liver-fluke microbes are in this river.

Primary_Text: wen' ake na ya ni, na wen' ni ake si gigi
Translated_Text: There's iron in it (the ore), and iron appears (when the ore is melted).
There is a lot of dust.
There is a village near Juba.

Primary_Text: Alima moa loaa kela hale iaia.

Primary_Text: Ma kahi o ka pake, loaa kela wahine pake ma ka lanai.

Ah, there's lots of grasshoppers everywhere!

Primary_Text: Li maanzhii diseu la tab ashteew.
Translated_Text: There is food on the table.

Primary_Text: Apipree trwaa saan kiiayaaw daa la saanblii.
Translated_Text: There were approximately three hundred people at the meeting.

Primary_Text: Iyave aen rwe pi la renn.
Translated_Text: There was a King and a Queen.

Primary_Text: Mituni maamashkayistaakwan ki la pat grenn istanee.
Translated_Text: It' very peculiar there are no berries this year.

Primary_Text: En  sontron   te   unu kmopo    a   skoro  alen e    kon.
Translated_Text: And sometimes when we came from school it rained.

Primary_Text: Dan  mi taki ai, a  no  pikinso  alen fadon.
Translated_Text: Then I said, ‘well, it rained a lot.' (Lit. 'it wasn't just a little rain that fell')
The rain has blown away a little (i.e.: It’s not raining so hard anymore.)

Primary_Text: Dí tjúba tá kái mbéi hen uwíi munjá tooná kó bè.
Translated_Text: It is raining so that her hair becomes wet and turns red.

Primary_Text: Mi án be waka go na a se anda di a alen be kai a kai.
Translated_Text: I did not go over there when the rain was falling heavily there (lit. I did not go the side over there when the rain was falling heavily there).
All of a sudden it starts to rain.

Primary_Text: Wen ih rein an ih blou iin truu di windou [...].
Translated_Text: When it rains and it blows in through the windows [...].

Primary_Text: [...] my two daughters been in it, they say if it raining and you marching, you can't stop, you know. You have to march in the rain.
Translated_Text: [...] if it rains and you march [in a parade], you can’t stop [...].

Primary_Text: So that mean when it rain it rain snow?
Translated_Text: [So that means that when] it rains [(in the winter in Europe) it rains snow]?

Primary_Text: E ain rain fa shree yeaah an six mont.
Translated_Text: It had not rained for three years and six months. (Lk 4.25)

Primary_Text: wɛn ì ren hɛvi jù no gò fit wɔka kam hiɛ
Translated_Text: When it rains heavily you won't be able to walk over here.

Translated_Text: That day when it was raining [...] it (the rain) carried so many animals away.
It has been raining for a long time [...].

Primary_Text: My too muchee fear makee rain.
Translated_Text: I'm afraid it is going to rain.

Primary_Text: Ren i kam long mipela nau.
yestedei i ren we i ren

Translated_Text: It's likely to rain on us.

Primary_Text: Naidaim, ooo, rein bina boldan, maidi tu, thri dei [...] binish.
Translated_Text: [During the] night, oh, the rain might have fallen, [for] maybe two [or] three days, [then it] finished.

Primary_Text: ɛnɛ ma koro di tafn di
Translated_Text: It will rain this afternoon. OR: Rain will fall this afternoon.

Primary_Text: Zóna di téra ki más ta txobe ê pértu di ekuador.
Translated_Text: The region of the earth where it rains most is near the equator.

Primary_Text: Si ka txobe, N ka ta simia.
Translated_Text: If it does not rain, I don't plant seeds.
The rain is going to fall.

Primary_Text: Grinhasin, txuva á ka ta dá na Kap Verd.
Translated_Text: Nowadays, it doesn't rain any more in Cape Verde.
It is raining (lit. The rain is raining).

Primary_Text: Uã dja tadji suba ska stlena.
Translated_Text: A certain afternoon it was drizzling.
It rains. OR: It is raining.

Translated_Text: It rains hard here during the rainy season.

Translated_Text: I am sure it can rain today.
It looks like it is going to rain.

Primary_Text: A monchè jodi a lapli a ap tonbe menm!
Translated_Text: My friend, it will surely rain today.
The rain is getting ready to fall.
It is raining. OR: Rain is falling.

Translated_Text: it rains; it is raining; it will rain

I feel cold. OR: It's cold

People had passed [here] before the rain.
Now, it has already started to rain.
That time there was a lot of rain.

Primary_Text: Jaise konciz pani giro ekdam kapara bij gaya.
Translated_Text: Like when, uh, it rained, [my] clothes got really wet.

Primary_Text: Nui loa ka ua a me ka wai.
Translated_Text: There is a lot of rain and water. OR: It's raining heavily (and the river is flooding).
Get up. We should go because its raining.
It is raining all the time. OR: There is rain all the time.
All the people want that it will rain. OR: All the people want rain.

A de kísi dà hedehátti toe.
Mi ede span span wan sortu fasi. Mi weri.

I have a headache. OR: I am suffering from a headache.
I have a headache. OR: My head is aching.
My head is hurting me (= I have a headache).

Primary_Text: I can't - like - he'p myself on de plane - sometime my head swing, an' I like to be 'long with somebody who I know.
[...] I wanted to prove to all of them that I wanted him, and I could have gotten him. I did, and I got the headaches that came along with it.
She does plague with headache all the time.

Translated_Text: My head hurts. OR: I have a headache.
I have a pain in my foot.

Primary_Text: sapos i ova long taem blong kakae, hed i mas soa

Translated_Text: Maybe he has got a headache, he is holding his head now.
when he had a stomach ache
When you have a strong headache.

Translated_Text: From the time I have been getting recurrent headaches, I have become forgetful.

Primary_Text: ɛk hafo sɛtɛ mɛto, bifibifi mɛto, frifrifu ʃi lefu, nununu di lefu wango sɛra
Translated_Text: I had to sit up with him, keep talking to him, keep rubbing his skin, keep pulling the skin where it hurt.

El ten dor na petu, el ten dor na kosta, el ten dor riba di kadera.

Mi, N ta k dor d'kabésa.

parim isti cuuvasu diiyaspa isti pee maam tudu paduva
Translated_Text: During the rainy season my legs and arms ache. OR: Speaker's translation: For me, in this rainy season, my legs and arms are all paining.

Primary_Text: Mi ta kere ku mi a forsa mi pia, pasobra ela lanta mashá doló mes awe.
Translated_Text: I believe I forced my leg, because it was very painful this morning on getting up.

Primary_Text: Mi pia ku mi a molestiá di mas ku hungamento di ping-pong no ta hasi doló mas.
Translated_Text: My leg, which I stressed while playing pingpong, is not hurting anymore.

Primary_Text: [...] i P. a haña mashá pero mashá dolor di kabes ku ela disidí di no sali mas.

Primary_Text: Si e pa danfèmal li genyen, e kèk maladi.
